rough gems.name: Azurite, Goethite, Limonite
rough gems.description: An intergrown aggregate of very sharp, dark midnight blue Azurite crystals covers all sides of a small amount of dark brown Limonite/Goethite gossan matrix.

rough gems.name: Corundum
rough gems.description: Gorgeous blood-red, partially gemmy ruby crystals on this remarkable, extremely rich small cabinet specimen from Jegdalek. The beautiful, lustrous stepped-growth crystals are set on all sides of the spare marble matrix. The striking, large, sharp, pseudo-octahedral crystal on the bottom is 2.6 cm, very large for the locale. Ex Chet Lemanski Collection. This is a classic, important and exceptionally rich small cabinet ruby specimen with fine color and a large crystal from the locale. It simply looks 'ruby' for color and luster, in a way that many specimens simply cannot do with impact. Cherry-red fluorescence. The fluorescence is simply breathtaking, as a bonus. NOTE: In LED lights, these look more pink-red. In room fluorescents, more classical red. In sunlight, sort of in between. Ruby like this has different color in different warmth of lighting.

rough gems.name: Fluorapatite, Muscovite, Calcite, Pyrite
rough gems.description: Group of eight intergrown, tabular, light lavender color hexagonal Fluorapatite crystals on crystallized Muscovite matrix. The largest Fluorapatite crystal is 1.3 cm across. Tabular, micro white Calcite crystals are also present, along with scattered micro Pyrite crystals.

rough gems.name: Malachite
rough gems.description: This is a very rare cabinet sized example of what some refer to as 'latticework' malachite pseudomorphs after azurite, from Tsumeb. They only came out once in this quality, I am not sure when - and they are today as rare as hen's teeth, especially at size. This is one of the better examples I have seen of the material, with sharp crystals of excellent color, individually reaching 6 cm in length. The piece is a complete floater, complete all around. All major crystals are either terminated sharply and only in a few cases, are some minor crystals in the spray a little rough on the tips due to odd growth features, but still complete nonetheless. This is a superb specimen, a rare style, and a beautiful geometry. Ex Allen Dillwith Collection (he sold off his Tsumeb suite to focus on other suites).

rough gems.name: Prehnite, Epidote
rough gems.description: Intergrown, light pistachio-green, translucent prehnite botryoids with nubby bladed surfaces nearly envelope lustrous, partially translucent olive-green epidote crystals on this sculptural and rich combination from 1990s to early 2000s finds in Mali. Fine prehnites from Mali, most often associated with deep green epidote crystals, are instantly recognizable to most collectors. See the 2011 Mineralogical Record article in Vol. 42, No. 3. A fine, representative small cabinet combination.

rough gems.name: Pyrite
rough gems.description: This pyrite cluster is from the world famous sharpest-of-sharp pyrite locality in Spain. These have been the gateway into collecting minerals for so many people over the decades since they started mining here for specimens, including Jack himself. The cubic crystals are well-formed and sharp. The satiny luster is quite good, and the faces have slight undulations that add definite character to the crystals. The largest pyrite crystal is 4.6 cm on edge and the piece is 600 grams in a small volume area, which is quite substantial. The quality of this small cabinet cluster are quite good, and it well-represents the family of great Spanish Pyrites. Jack obtained it from the great old Spanish dealer, Luis Leite (leitite). There are numerous references to Jack and his collection in print, but perhaps a good tour of the collection and its history will help give perspective on just how good, and important, this collection is:

rough gems.name: Wulfenite
rough gems.description: Impressive opposing tabular wulfenite crystals atop highlight this classic, older, rich and aesthetic small cabinet triangular plate covered with classic 'sandwich' style crystals from the renowned Erupcion Mine at Los Lamentos. The richly colored zoned prisms, to 2.0 cm, are translucent to opaque, adding character. It is starkly geometric, and this is a style known for its shape rather than its color - but unique to this day. The striking pair atop look like pages of an open book or wings of a bird or butterfly. Read about the famed locale in the 2003 Mineralogical Record article in Vol. 34, No. 6. Ex Bill Panczner Collection, of which Mexico was the primary specialty. Bill was the first Curator of Earth Science at the Arizona Sonora Desert Museum in 1974 and the author of the 1987 book Minerals of Mexico. It is the most thorough summary of the subject.
